sentence: They gave me a beautiful book, Dutch Sagas and Legends, but they gave me Volume II by mistake, so I exchanged two other books for Volume I. Aunt Helene brought me a puzzle, Aunt Stephanie a darling brooch and Aunt Leny a terrific book: Daisy Goes to the Mountains.

From Daddy and Mama I got a blue blouse, a game, a bottle of grape juice, which to my mind tastes a bit like wine (after all, wine is made from grapes), a puzzle, a jar of cold cream, 2.50 guilders and a gift certificate for two books.

I got another book as well, Camera Obscura (but Margot already has it, so I exchanged mine for something else), a platter of homemade cookies (which I made myself, of course, since I’ve become quite an expert at baking cookies), lots of candy and a strawberry tart from Mother.
I’d call him Rin Tin Tin too, and I’d take him to school with me, where he could stay in the janitor’s room or by the bicycle racks when the weather was good.
Ilse Wagner, Hanneli Goslar and Jacqueline van Maarsen came home with me after gym, since we’re in the same class.
People who saw us together used to say, “There goes Anne, Hanne and Sanne.” I only met Jacqueline van Maarsen when I started at the Jewish Lyceum, and now she’s my best friend.
A little after seven I went to Daddy and Mama and then to the living room to open my presents, and you were the first thing I saw, maybe one of my nicest presents.
Ilse is Hanneli’s best friend, and Sanne goes to another school and has friends there.
This morning I lay in the bathtub thinking how wonderful it would be if I had a dog like Rin Tin Tin.
Afterward they all danced around me in a circle and sang “Happy Birthday.” When I got home, Sanne Ledermann was already there.
I’ll begin from the moment I got you, the moment I saw you lying on the table among my other birthday presents.
Hanneli and Sanne used to be my two best friends.
As it was my birthday, I got to decide which game my classmates would play, and I chose volleyball.
During recess I passed out cookies to my teachers and my class, and then it was time to get back to work.
When I couldn’t wait any longer, I went to the dining room, where Moortje (the cat) welcomed me by rubbing against my legs.
I didn’t arrive home until five, since I went to gym with the rest of the class.
On Friday, June 12, I was awake at six o’clock, which isn’t surprising, since it was my birthday.
Then Hanneli came to pick me up, and we went to school.
(I’m not allowed to take part because my shoulders and hips tend to get dislocated.)
But I’m not allowed to get up at that hour, so I had to control my curiosity until quarter to seven.
Then a bouquet of roses, some peonies and a potted plant.
And a letter from Grammy, right on time, but of course that was just a coincidence.
(I went along when you were bought, but that doesn’t count.)
